Summary

Russian forces have launched an invasion of Ukraine, with troops entering the country from the east, from Belarus in the north, and Crimea in the south.

Russian President Vladimir Putin delivered a televised address, announcing a military operation to demilitarise and â€˜de-nazifyâ€™ Ukraine.

Ukraineâ€™s air defence systems have largely been disabled.

Multiple cities across the country have been struck by missiles and artillery shells, including Kyiv, Odessa, Kharkiv, and Mariupol.

Ukraine has declared a state of emergency and closed its airspace to all civilian traffic.

Road and rail routes out of the country are largely congested due to the number of people attempting to evacuate.

Situation

Early on 24 February, Russian President Vladimir Putin delivered a televised address to the nation during which he announced the commencement of a military operation to demilitarise and â€˜de-nazifyâ€™ Ukraine. President Putin warned other countries against inhibiting Russiaâ€™s actions in Ukraine, stating that Russiaâ€™s actions would lead to â€œconsequences that you have never faced in your historyâ€. While Vladimir Putin was still talking, multiple explosions were reported around the Ukrainian city of Mariupol. Following this, explosions targeted areas of Kyiv, Kharkiv, Odessa, Ivano-Frankivsk, and more. The Russian forces subsequently launched a campaign to disable Ukraineâ€™s air defence systems, primarily targeting military airbases.



Following the initial stages, columns of Russian ground forces entered Ukrainian territory from the east, from Belarus in the north, and from Crimea in the south. Armed clashes have occurred between Ukrainian and Russian forces in multiple areas of the country. The use of thermobaric, cruise and ballistic missile systems has been documented, primarily against military structures. One of the heaviest confrontations is believed to be around Antonov International Airport in Hostomel, approximately 25 kilometres northwest of central Kyiv. Videos have been shared online showing Russian attack helicopters surrounding the airport, with large columns of smoke emerging from the site.

Ground forces are also believed to be engaging in combat at the airport. The level of fighting in close proximity to Kyiv has raised concerns that Russian forces will attempt to capture the capital city in the coming hours. Heavy fighting has also been recorded around the Antonovskiy Bridge, leading into Kherson, and Russian forces are believed to have entered the city. Valerii Zaluzhnyi, the Chief of Staff of the Ukrainian Armed Forces, has alleged that four ballistic missiles have been fired from Belarusian territory in the southwest direction.

The President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, announced that Russian forces are attempting to gain control of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant, calling the action â€œa declaration of war against the whole of Europeâ€. Although the primary targets appear to be military bases and infrastructure, civilian casualties have been documented on several occasions. A video has surfaced showing a fighter jet firing at least two rockets towards a civilian housing complex. The exact figures of civilian and military fatalities are unavailable.



The previous night, Ukraineâ€™s Verkhovna Rada approved a 30-day state of emergency to be imposed at midnight. The state of emergency allows the countryâ€™s authorities to restrict freedom of movement, inspect vehicles, "strengthen the protection of public order", restrict the sale of alcohol and weapons, prohibit public gatherings, impose curfews, and regulate broadcast outlets. Then, following the invasion, the Ukrainian government imposed martial law and closed the countryâ€™s airspace. Currently, civilian flights are disallowed from operating services to and from Ukraine, limiting evacuation options. Multiple roads leading west have become heavily congested, due to the volume of people attempting to evacuate the country. Likewise, videos surfaced today showing large crowds queuing outside Kyivâ€™s main railway station (Pasazhyrskyi), implying that rail options are also congested.

Russiaâ€™s actions have been met with widespread international condemnation. The United Kingdomâ€™s Prime Minister, Boris Johnson, delivers a televised address during which he denounced Russiaâ€™s actions, labelling President Putin as a â€œdictatorâ€, and stated that a â€œmassive packageâ€ of sanctions will be imposed, asserting â€œwe will do whatever it takesâ€ to support Ukraine. Moldova and Latvia have both declared a state of emergency, while the Finnish Prime Minister, Sanna Marin, has announced that her country is ready to apply for NATO membership, â€œif it becomes a matter of national securityâ€. Jens Stoltenberg, the Secretary General of NATO, has labelled the invasion as a â€œbrutal act of warâ€ and announced that the bloc is increasing its presence in the eastern European members and heightening the readiness of the NATO Response Force. At an emergency United Nations Security Council meeting, each member was largely critical of the Russian invasion, and the Ukrainian ambassador to the United Nations, Sergiy Kyslytsya, stated that Russia has declared war on Ukraine.



Analysis and Implications

The Russian authorities are believed to have several objectives in conducting its invasion of Ukraine. Primarily, it is understood that Russia is seeking to remove the incumbent Ukrainian authorities from power. Russia views the post-2014 Ukrainian governments as a threat to its national security, hence the operation to demilitarise the country. It remains to be seen whether Russia will annex any more of Ukraineâ€™s territory. However, it is probable that if Russia is successful in removing Ukraineâ€™s administration, it will install a new pro-Russian government. In such an event, it is possible that an insurgency will be carried out by the Ukrainian population, something that is being actively encouraged by the countryâ€™s armed forces.

President Zelensky announced that Ukraine will give weapons to anyone willing to defend it, stating that people should â€œbe ready to support Ukraine in the squares of our citiesâ€. If this occurs, it is possible that Russian troops could remain in Ukraine for an extended period to quell any pockets of resistance. Already, videos have surfaced showing troops from Rosgvardiya deployed inside Ukrainian territory, specifically, in Henichesk, situated in the Kherson Oblast. Rosgvardiya constitutes Russiaâ€™s domestic armed forces who have previously been deployed to Belarus in order to quell protest activities. This suggests that the Russian government is planning a long-term operation in Ukraine.



The invasion of Ukraine is already having impacts on global financial markets, and sanctions are likely to worsen the situation. In the immediate aftermath of the invasionâ€™s commencement, the value of the Russian rouble fell by approximately 20 percent, before achieving a slight recovery. The price of oil has reached its highest level since 2014, at 105 USD per barrel. The FTSE 100 share index fell this morning by 3 percent, London-listed Russian company Sberbankâ€™s share price fell by 61 percent and Gazpromâ€™s fell by 28 percent. Wheat prices have also increased sharply, to approximately 390 USD per tonne, which is thought to be the largest price rise for nine years. The full scale of economic impact remains to be seen, but fuel and gas prices are expected to rise.



The risk to traveller safety is critical, civilian fatalities have been reported on multiple occasions and there is no guarantee that fighting will happen exclusively outside civilian zones. Worsening the risk, are the limited availability of transport options. With all civilian flights suspended alongside road and rail options being heavily congested, it is likely that difficulties will arise when attempting to evacuate the country. Ukrainian authorities have set up bomb shelters in the major cities, including the capital, many of which are in underground railway stations.

The United States Embassy to Ukraine currently advises that people should shelter-in-place. Both sides have accused the other of spreading lies and launching disinformation campaigns, indicating that verifiable information is limited, possibility impeding the ability of travellers to keep abreast of the current situation.





Advice

Defer all non-essential travel to Ukraine.

Ensure that travel passports and travel documents are up to date and regularly review possible departure options.

Where applicable, travellers in Ukraine should familiarise themselves with plans to evacuate the country and/or implement robust security measures.

Regularly monitor reputable national and international news reports for situational updates over the coming days and weeks, keeping in mind the rifeness of disinformation campaigns.

Timeline - February 24, 2022

All times UTC



1525: Mayor of Kyiv announces city-wide curfew from 2200-0700 local time.



1426: Video posted on social media purports to show Russian military vehicles crossing the Antonovsky bridge and entering Kherson city, a suburb of Antonivka, located about 451 kilometers (280 miles) south-southeast of Kyiv.



1410: Reports emerge that a hospital in Vuhledar, Donetsk Oblast, has been struck by Russian munitions, allegedly causing four civilian fatalities and injuring six others.



1400: Videos emerge showing civilian fatalities and structural damages in Mariupol.



1355: Reuters reports that an unidentified missile has struck southern Kyiv, causing damage to structures. Details of possible injuries have not been specified.



1350: U.S. President Joe Biden convenes National Security Council to discuss the situation in Ukraine. POTUS to deliver update on the Russia-Ukraine situation at 1730 UTC.



1340: Videos surface appearing to show Rosgvardiya troops in Henichesâ€™k, in the Kherson Oblast.



1340: The Ukrainian Ministry of Defense announces that four ballistic missiles have been launched from the territory of Belarus in the southwestern direction.



1335: The Czech Republic announces it is suspending the granting of visas to Russian citizens.



1330: The Ministry of Defense of Ukraine reports that as of 1500 local time, fighting is continuing along the entire line of contact and that three Russian tanks have been destroyed.



1330: The Russian armed forces claim to have destroyed 74 objects of Ukrainian military infrastructure and additionally claim that 14 Ukrainian soldiers have surrendered in the Donbas region.



1320: Air raid sirens are sounded in Kyiv.



1315: Videos emerge purporting to show shelling in the village of Trypilla, 40 kilometers (25 miles) south of central Kyiv.



1310: The Ukrainian State Border Guard stated that its forces are engaged with Russian troops on the outskirts of Sumy.



1310: Videos surface showing ten Ukrainian T-64BV tanks in the Kherson region, all of which have been destroyed.



1300: Deputies evacuated from Ukraineâ€™s Verkhovna Rada in Kyiv.



1300: Images surface showing a Russian helicopter being shot down over Vyshhorod.



1255: Videos surface showing large explosions at the airbase near Melitopolâ€™.



1240: Reports surface of civilians in Kharkiv unloading firearms from a vehicle, preparing to fight Russian soldiers.



1240: Reports surface stating that a Ukrainian military aircraft has crashed near Kyiv, killing 14 people who were onboard. It is unclear if the aircraft was shot down or not.



1230: Russian forces are believed to be in control of Antonov International Airport (IATA: GML) in Homostelâ€™, near Kyiv.



1210: NATO Secretary General Stoltenberg says alliance has no plans to deploy forces to Ukraine.



1205: Reports surface of Russian special forces conducting operations in Kyiv, particularly in the government areas.



1200: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson delivers a televised address, during which he condemns Russiaâ€™s actions and states that a â€œmassive packageâ€ of sanctions will be imposed on Russia, and that the country â€œwill do whatever it takesâ€ to support Ukraine.



1155: Reports surface of Russian and Ukrainian fighter jets engaging in combat around Kyiv.



1135: Videos surface taken on the E40, near Kharkiv, showing several destroyed Russian vehicles alongside one dead soldier.



1130: Reports surface of burning grain silos in Umanâ€™, Cherkasy Oblast.



1125: NATO Secretary General, Jens Stoltenberg, delivers a live speech during which he states that NATO is initiating its active defense plans, allowing a deployment of the NATO Response Force.



1115: Numerous Russian attack helicopters are seen flying over Homostelâ€™ in the Kyiv Oblast, under 30 kilometers (18 miles) from the center of the capital city.



1100: Media sources report seeing smoke rising over the headquarters of the Ministry of Defense of Ukraine in Kyiv.



1100: Russian Mi-24/35M and Mi-28N attack helicopters are seen flying over the Kakhova hydroelectric plant on the Dnieper river.



1100: Russian-state controlled media reports that two civilian cargo ships have been struck by Ukrainian missiles in the Sea of Azov, no other official confirmation has been received.



1100: Ukrainian authorities claim to have shot down three Russian helicopters near Antonov International Airport (IATA: GML).



1040: Ukrainian authorities claim to have shot down a total of five Russian aircraft.



1025: Belarus announces large parts of its airspace are closed to civilian traffic for an indefinite period.



0955: President Zelensky announces that Ukraine is severing diplomatic ties with Russia, and that the government will give weapons to anyone willing to defend Ukraine, stating â€œbe ready to support Ukraine in the squares of our citiesâ€.



0900: Moldova declares a state of emergency and closes its airspace; flights en route to the country are being diverted.



0830: The General Staff of the Armed Forces of Ukraine issues an update stating that Ukrainian forces successfully halted the advance of Russian forces in the city of Chernihiv.



0805: Poland, Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania invoke NATO Article 4 to table concerns over threats to territorial integrity, political independence, and/or security with Alliance members.



0750: Journalists report hearing sirens multiple times across Lviv, as authorities urged city residents to take cover.



0715: Video footage on social media shows Russian ground forces on the outskirts of Kharkiv city.



0709: Widespread mobile phone disruptions reported throughout Ukraine, including outages in Chernivtsi, Odesa, and Lviv oblasts.



0650: Video footage on social media shows significant traffic jams heading west from the center of Kyiv.



0605: President Charles Michel of the European Council and President Ursula von der Leyen of the European Commission issue statement condemning Russiaâ€™s military aggression and calling on Russia to â€œimmediately cease the hostilities and withdraw its military from Ukraine.â€ EU member state leaders plan to hold an emergency summit on Thursday evening.



0600: Ukrainian authorities claim to have shot down up to five Russian planes and one helicopter in Luhansk, though such reports have subsequently been denied by Moscow.



0530: Explosion, large smoke plume filmed at Kherson International Airport (IATA: KHE) in Ukraineâ€™s southern city of Kherson.



0450: CCTV shows Russian mechanized infantry units advance across the border from Veselovka, Belarus into Senkivka, Ukraine.



0445: The Ukrainian Interior Ministry claims that the invasion had already resulted in â€œhundreds of casualties,â€ though no further details were specified.



0430: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy declared nationwide indefinite martial law amid the ongoing Russian invasion. The government has also urged all citizens to seek shelter from the Russian bombardment.



0300 - 0430: Initial explosions targeting Ukrainian infrastructure, primarily military installations, have occurred in various cities near Ukraineâ€™s borders and in the capital city of Kyiv early Thursday morning. Explosions were reported in Berdyans'k, Bila Tserkva, Boryspil, Dnipro, Ivano-Frankivsk, Kharkiv, Kherson, Kramatorsk, Kyiv, Mariupol, Mykolaiv, and Odesa.



Cross-border incursion of Russian ground forces reported in Ukraineâ€™s northeastern city of Kharkiv. Pro-Russian forces in the self-declared, breakaway republics of Luhansk and Donetsk advanced across the line of contact, reportedly seizing multiple villages including Horodyshche and Milove.



0300: Russian President Vladimir Putin announces the beginning of a â€œspecial military operationâ€ in Ukraine. He proclaimed that Russia intends to â€œdemilitarizeâ€ Ukraine, and called on the nationâ€™s armed forces to surrender. Moments later, the Ukrainian Interior Ministry warned that the invasion had begun, with reports of explosions in multiple cities.

Ukraine Support Services

With ongoing tensions in Ukraine, Anvil is able to offer bespoke service packages to those who may have personnel in or around this region.

These service packages can include:

Intelligence Support in the form of daily situation updates, risk summaries and city/region specific awareness reports

Evacuation Consultation and Planning

Dedicated Security Assets in region

Medical Emergency Response Plans

In Country Expat Crisis Support

Speak with one of our experienced team directly on +44(0)20 7938 4221 (UK) or +1 (813) 514-6276 (US) for further details on the specialist support packages available.
